2) were invented in the 1590s. They work by passing through the specimen.
They let us see things like and and we can also use them to study .
3) were invented in the 1930s. They use rather than .
Electron microscopes have a higher and than light microscopes, so they let
us see much in like the of mitochondria and chloroplasts.
This has allowed us to have a much of and the

(although they can’t be used to view living cells).
Gather your microscopes, comrades — it’s the bio resolution...
There’s lots of important stuff here about how you use a light microscope to view specimens — so get learning.
Q1A student prepares a slide with a sample of onion cells and places it on the stage of a light microscope.
Describe the steps she should take to get a focused image of the cells.[4 marks]
Without we would never have discovered cells. We can even use them to look cells.

the specimen in place. Then use to place your specimen on the slide.

8)If you need to see your specimen with , swap to a
(e.g. if your FOV was 5 mm then you swap to a lens that is 10 times more
powerful, your FOV will now be 5 mm ÷ 10 = 0.5 mm).
